awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ABI Sustaining:  The National Center for Genome Analysis Support
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of genomes is a critical and rapidly growing component in understanding the variability of life, biological functions, population dynamics, and how organisms respond to external influences. Genomics has qualitatively improved our ability to investigate biological dynamics and to make important discoveries that are the foundations for understanding topics such as environmental change, developing and protecting crops, and improving health outcomes. Genome analysis, however, can be a significant challenge for the practicing biologist. Many biologists who need to undertake genome science are not sufficiently expert in the relevant analytical tools, or the complex workflows required to get from the initial data generated by sequencers to a biologically-meaningful analyzed result. In addition, many do not have access to the advanced computing and large-scale storage resources required for processing and managing genomics data. The National Center for Genome Analysis Support (NCGAS) addresses these challenges by providing an integrated service comprised of expert bioinformatics consulting and educational services, hardened and optimized software available through easy-to-use web-based workflow management tools, advanced computing systems, and large scale data storage and publishing facilities. NCGAS services are particularly important in enabling important contributions from researchers from smaller institutions and other groups with limited access to their own resources.

NCGAS works through the following goals to fulfill its mission to enable the biological research community of the US to analyze, understand, and make use of the vast amount of genomic information now available:  provide excellent bioinformatics consulting services to biologists doing research in the areas of transcriptome- and genome-level assembly; deliver genome assembly and analysis software on national cyberinfrastructure (CI) systems and provide tools for download and installation on campus CI resources; provide training, education, and outreach programs on genome analysis; improve the quality and functionality of bioinformatics software; enable the use of large-memory compute clusters designed specifically to support genome analysis; and provide mechanisms to store and distribute genome research data and products. These efforts will enable and accelerate scientific discoveries by researchers who make use of NCGAS services, lower barriers for scientists to create, execute, document, and share genomics analyses, help identify best-in-class genomics analysis software and provide improved versions of these software to the community, enhance the technology literacy of practicing scientists, and help grow the bioinformatics workforce. Outcomes of this project will be made available at https://ncgas.org and https://github.com/NCGAS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Center for Genome Analysis Support (NCGAS) was originally created by a previous award from NSF to Indiana University (IU) in 2011 to help bridge the gap between biologists seeking to analyze increasing amounts of genome sequence data and the available national computing resources available to support those analyses. NCGAS became a "scientific service center" focused on helping genomics researchers take full advantage of advances in computing technology to make important biological discoveries. 

In 2015, Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) joined IU as a partner in NCGAS, with both institutions receiving collaborative awards to sustain NCGAS as a service center to enable discoveries through genome analysis. Through this award, PSC made its high performance data analysis systems and computational expertise available to the NCGAS community, and leveraged its connection with the NSF's eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) to help more biologists get the help they needed using these advanced resources provided by NSF. 

For the three years of this award, NCGAS has continued to address challenges in genome analysis by helping the national biological research community to use advanced computing resources for their analyses, providing genomics consulting services, maintaining, supporting, and delivering genome analysis software on national computing systems, and providing training, education, and outreach programs.

NCGAS has helped increase the number of biologists who are able to effectively use state-of-the-art genomics tools and advanced computing. Through a collaboration with the Galaxy Project (usegalaxy.org), anyone in the world can use advanced national computing infrastructure at PSC for de novo genome and transcriptome assembly simply by submitted their workflows from usegalaxy.org. We have also built a repository of bioinformatics Singularity containers (https://github.com/pscedu/singularity) that can be used to run bioinformatics workflows across computing systems on national or local campus infrastructure. Additionally, through one-on-one NCGAS consulting, along with targeted group trainings, biologists have successfully completed research projects that would otherwise have been impossible or would have taken much longer. These biologists are now helping disseminate these skills throughout their research groups and community, further accelerating this important work.

As a result, NCGAS has enabled biologists to reconstruct and analyze the full genome sequence of many important organisms and communities of organisms, leading to key insights into how living things work.  Recently, NCGAS supported several groundbreaking studies, including a global metagenomic map of urban microbiomes, insight into the biology of spaceflight, and the discovery of a male X chromosome in a mammalian species. Insights derived from these and other studies will help enable breakthroughs in medicine, agriculture, conservation, energy, and many other things that affect our daily lives.
